BE11:15am

Restructuring Reserves for a Cyclical Turn - Citing a rise in social inflation, claims handling costs and adverse reserve development, Hiscox has decided to take action in advance of what could be the first turn in the casualty cycle since the early 2000's. This action has taken the form of 3 changes:

Strengthening existing Director's & Officer's liability reserves
Changing reserving methodology to hold casualty reserves longer
Record new casualty claims at higher loss picks
These measures should leave Hiscox with higher reserve buffers in the back book, sustainable recognition of releases and more prudent front book margins.

FT_reader Please can we cover a stock that Bryce is enthusiastic about?
Dr B Morning all
VV75 @FT_reader, you mean like Fevertree?
BE11:15am

Earnings cost across the medium term - However, the cost of such prudence is lower profitability, both in 2019 earnings and across the medium term, in 2020 and 2021. Management suggested that a reasonable glide path for future margins would be for the 97%-99% in 2019 to fall to 96%-98% in 2020 and 95%-97% in 2021, implying that returning to the 90%-95% target range is unlikely in the near term, as the impact of these changes earns through the book. In our model, this results in additional earnings cuts of greater than 30% for 2019, greater than 10% for 2020 and greater than 10% for 2021.

2s10s @FT_reader: Bryce is professionally dour on all stocks.
RiskyBoy I will probably miss the last ML session tomorrow, but I just wanted to thank Bryce for all these years of ML. I hardly ever post comments (IT Compliance does not like it) but I read most sessions live or delayed later in the day. I found ML both entertaining and informative, and Bryce’s dark humour was an added bonus. It will be sorely missed.
Grouchmonkey Remember Bryce was very keen on Barclays at one point - or was that Paul Murphy?
BE11:16am

Valuation implications - In this context, we believe the market may struggle to settle on a valuation for Hiscox. With the shares rated at a considerable premium to peers, we would suggest that some downside is warranted, albeit management prudence means that the stock should still arguably trade at a premium to peers. Moreover, given the other issues the warning highlighted, such as catastrophe losses, fees and profit commission, this warning would seem to present all the negative news at once, reducing the likelihood of any further negative catalysts from here. In this note we thus reassess our valuation assumptions, making the case that the through-cycle combined ratio is probably higher than previously thought, but that the long-term growth rate should remain unchanged.

BarristerM Thinking about the companies that have received the most sustained, rigorous negative scrutiny from BE & co, should we be predicting a relief rebound for Wirecard & Purple Bricks on Monday?
erlkin bag the micro ....let's talk macro...big pic...forecasts for a reunion.....ftse, dow, nikkei etc...oil.....gold......kardashians....bitcoin....yadda
YourGrannyOnBongos @2s10s - pronounced 'do-er' of course, not 'dower'
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Casualty Catastrophe - In terms of the underlying concerns that prompted changes, Hiscox noted that it was "just starting to see the beginning of social inflation" and that "claims are taking longer to settle", leading to higher billable hours paid to third-party lawyers. In our view, all of these are symptomatic of a claims severity problem, where plaintiffs refuse to settle and demand higher compensation. In this case, the costs of both claims handling and claims settlement rises. Currently, management suggests that this problem is impacting 20% of the US casualty book in Hiscox Retail, although prices rises to compensate for this should soon begin to earn through and limit the impact.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

In our view it is
clear that the actions being undertaken to address US casualty will have a
multi-year impact on Retail profits, suggesting significant downside to
consensus estimates. This is driven by: 1) a change in reserving policy
toward slower recognition of favorable developments across the Retail
division; and 2) increased initial loss picks due to an expectation of higher
claims. The impact of this, in combination with three consecutive years of
high catastrophe losses in big-ticket areas, is that Hiscox’s capital
flexibility is likely to be much reduced in our view, and we believe several
periods of positive performance may be required before the market’s
confidence is fully restored. For this reason we are more concerned by
further downside risk than looking for buying opportunities, and
downgrade to Neutral (from OW). Our EPS estimates fall by
70%/17%/14% to reflect the announcements.

BE11:18am

Reserving actions on US casualty. The actions being taken on reserves
are not directly an impact of higher large claims, but rather an
expectation that future claims experience will be higher. Hiscox states
that it is seeing an increased propensity for US claimants to seek
damages, and also that claims are taking longer to settle. Legal costs are
therefore being pushed higher, even in areas not exposed to very large
payouts. This has prompted Hiscox to increase its initial loss picks, and
also adjust its reserving policy across the retail division, which will now
require more experience before positive developments are recognized.

BE11:18am

Hiscox does not directly comment on its capital
position at Q3 but in our view any surplus over the S&P rating
requirement is likely to be limited. We see this as the binding constraint
for Hiscox, and therefore believe the company will want to work to
rebuild flexibility as soon as it can. We do not see the dividend as at risk
but now assume no dividend growth for the year.

cracklenpop And so, the end is nearAnd so I face the final curtain...
BE11:19am

A more cautious approach to casualty reserving and attritional weakness drove this guidance cut. HSX now doesn't expect a return to the 90-95% Retail COR target range until 2022E; 2020/21E guidance is rebased materially lower. We unpick this guidance below, but note it appears conservative (as one might expect from a re-basing exercise) in that 1) no price increases are factored in and 2) HSX is not actually seeing any reserve creep, it is simply building prudence. We remain Neutral; even though earnings downgrade potential is now 'in the shop window', valuation remains elevated.

BE11:19am

2019E Retail COR guidance (97-99%) is ~2-4ppt above the target range. ~1-2ppt is driven by higher loss picks and lower releases to build reserve prudence. The remainder is driven by a weak attritional loss ratio. HSX now guides the Retail COR to 96-98% in 2020E, 95-97% in 2021E and 90-95% in 2022E. Within this guidance, HSX keeps the reserve drag constant, given uncertain industry casualty trends. Planned improvement is driven by management actions to address attritional weakness, including in-housing the US legal function to better control legal claims management costs.

BE11:21am

he $190m estimated impact from Dorian, Faxai and Hagibis is expected to be materially above the company’s full year catastrophe budget. This is also before any impact from the Californian wildfires. London Market has also seen $30m higher claims across many lines, including US D&O. On top of this, Retail is expected to miss its medium-term combined ratio target of 90-95% at 97-99%. Against previous guidance of a sub-$100m reserve release in H2, the company is now guiding to a small positive reserve development for the full year.

BE11:21am

he sum of these impacts implies a low (sub $50m) full year profit against current consensus of c.$275m. While investment income was in-line in Q3, this outcome would be the third year in a row of single digit ROEs or below. We continue to struggle to reconcile this performance with a close to 20x forward PE multiple and c.2.7x historic tangible NAV, while recognising that there are real growth opportunities for the Hiscox franchise.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

While forward looking statements are limited, momentum for rate increases in loss-affected areas is positive. Against this, our current forecasts assume $250m of reserve releases in FY20E – given current claims inflation and activity and the small release guided for this year, that assumption looks very optimistic, but is a major contributor to our c$330m PBT forecast (we are broadly in-line with consensus). Management has re-iterated its medium-term target of 90-95% combined ratio in Retail.

BE11:30am

H1 Underlying PBT of £238m was +2.5% ahead of consensus estimates (£232m), although largely in line with guidance of above £229m (-£50m YoY, slightly offset by a smaller IFRS 16 drag in H1 this year). The beat on this line was much smaller as finance costs came in much higher than consensus expectation.

The company has guided towards PBT and not towards EBIT. Given all the recent changes (IFRS16, different H1 to H2 phasing, Argos integration) it should not be surprising that at EBIT level, the gap between results and consensus is much bigger. It just implies that sell-side didn’t spend too much time modelling the finance line (materially impacted by IFRS16)

H1 Underlying EBIT £457m was +£34m (+8%) ahead of consensus, entirely driven by Retail EBIT beating estimates by +8.4%, with margins of 2.95% +22bps ahead of expectations. Whilst a -32bps step down YoY, this was driven by previously-highlighted technical impacts of: (1) phasing of cost savings, (2) higher marketing costs and (3) tough weather comps. H2 will benefit from annualising out last year's wage increases, as well as a normalisation of marketing costs and weather comps. As above, we don't make much of this beat.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Outlook unchanged, divi rejig effectively unchanged.

leckford RIP MLThanks BE
BE11:31am

Dividend policy change. SBRY is changing its divi pay-out ratio policy from 2X cover on a pre-IFRS16 basis to a pay-out ratio policy of 1.9X cover on a post IFRS16 basis. As IFRS16 lower SBRY's EPS by about 5%, this pay-out ratio change allows the company to keep same dividend cash pay-out despite the change in accounting. SBRY is focussing on cash generation and making this changes ensures that investors are not worse off because of the accounting change.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

While conscious of the bottom up risks to the reiterated FY guidance, we are also alert to the possibilities of an improving UK environment once a new Parliament is voted in. Recent polling suggests that an outright Conservative majority looks like the most probable outcome. The extension of which should be a swift, managed Brexit. From an industry perspective the double whammy of reducing COGS pressures (on £ revaluation) and more assured consumer spending would provide a lift to all. But this is still supposition (SBRY noted the market remains tough), so our preference goes to grocers with a clearer path to FY delivery and non-food stocks which display a stronger upgrade leverage to that scenario.

BE11:42am

AML reported 3Q19 revenues of ~£250m and an adj. Ebit of £13.4m,
roughly in-line with our expectations of ~£10m. Importantly AML
delivered six of the DB4 GT Zagato Continuations in Q3, with 13 left for
Q4. We cut our earnings estimates for 2019 (new adj. Ebit 2019: £60m) on
the back of lower underlying earnings in Q3 (we expected Q3 2019 Ebit to
be ~£10m without DB4 deliveries), continued core ASP pressure, and
wholesale volume cut from 6.1k to ~6k. In terms of FCF, we expect a
positive fourth quarter but pressure again in 1H 2020 from multiple
upcoming launches. We look forward to hearing more on the cost cutting
plan to be announced by AML in Feb 2020.

BE11:43am

2019 outlook: Total wholesale guidance was cut from 6.2-6.4k units to
the lower end of consensus expectations (6-6.5k) vs. JPMe of 6.1k. On
adj. Ebit, AML now expects ~£67m for 2019 (vs. prev. JPMe: £67m and
consensus at £73m), with ~£90m still to be delivered in 4Q.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Core portfolio. AML mentioned that the segment of the market in
which Vantage competes is declining and that demand remains weaker
than plans. Deliveries of DBS Superleggera Volante commenced in Q3
and Vantage AMR deliveries start in Q4. Vantage Roadster deliveries
will start in spring 2020. DBX is on track with the global launch in
Beijing on the 20th of November. First production trial is completed with
SoP in Q2 2020. The ramp-up of the Valkyrie is expected to reach runrate
maturity of deliveries in the second half of 2020.

Aston Martin stepped away from their own guidance for the full year, as a
nresult of lower volumes and continuing macro uncertainties. They do, however, expect to be able to “meet market financial expectations” which we read as a number close to consensus. We note consensus wholesale expectations of 6.22k units (GSe 6.19k units) are c.3% below the mid-point of AM’s guide while cons margin of 19% (GSe 16%) is 100bps shy of the company’s previously guided c.20%. Overall, we estimate this aggregates to an approximate earnings downgrade of -2 to -9%.

BE11:46am

AM’s cash finished the quarter at £110 mn, down on Q2’s £127mn but better
nthan what we had forecast (GSe £77mn). Negative FCF of -£44mn was better than what we had assumed (GSe -£53mn), no doubt helped by the continuation models. Q3 numbers were not impacted by the Senior Secured Note Issuance ($150mn) and subsequent repayment of other borrowings (c.£90mn) which took place after the quarter end and should provide a small benefit at Q4. AM finished the quarter with net debt of £800mn (GSe £802mn), up from £732mn at Q2, and reported adj. net leverage of 5.5x LTM (GSe 5.5x). We wait for further details on R&D capitalization to calculate the leverage on a cash EBITDA basis.

BE11:52am

United Utilities drew up a very cost-conscious business plan (bill reductions of 13%), that obtained ‘enhanced’ (ie fast track) status from Ofwat in the spring. UU management has also done everything it can to derisk its business: prepaying pension contributions; keeping modest gearing; increasing its dividend by no more than RPI over the current five year period; and working on increasing efficiencies on a bottom up basis through ‘Systems Thinking.’ Despite all of these efforts, its pursuit of further concessions from Ofwat has conversely led to being set more challenging targets post the slow-tracked companies’ interim determination in July and increased the likelihood of a dividend cut.

BE11:52am

Ofwat now has to decide whether to benchmark its allowed returns at
the Final Determination due 16 December to falling Gilt yields. Ofwat observed at its City Briefing in July, that, since its look forward view of 2.83% (CPIH real), its allowed return could fall a further c40bp. If we were to assume this, UU would pay out c106% of its earnings for the next five years. Even if we exclude deferred tax from our earnings calculation (as its peers do), this still represents c100% payout. Also, as UU’s Regulatory Capital Value (RCV) is declining over the next five years, we cannot assume that its earnings will be flattered by capital allowances. We note from consensus that several analysts have assumed dividend cuts for 2020/21 in their estimates.

madrugada RSA?
BE11:54am

We value United Utilities using a combination of three methodologies – DCF, dividend yield and sum-of-the-parts (SOTP). We assign a 50% weight to yield and 25% each to DCF and SOTP, rounded up to arrive at our new target price of 760p (previously 860p). We have updated our estimates post trading statement. In DCF we maintain beta at 0.8. However, updated estimates and repricing the stock to the last closing price cut our valuation. We roll forward the dividend in yield valuation to represent our latest view of a dividend cut in FY2021. We retain a 5% yield for 2020/21 on this lower dividend. In our SOTP we have updated the estimates which reduces our valuation. Our TP declines from 860p to 760p implying 9.9% downside; given the stock’s strong recent performance, which we think is unjustified, we cut our rating to Reduce. UU is trading at 7.2% premium to its March 2020e RCV. We think risk of a lower allowed return given Gilt rates decline since the FD increases its downside risk.

The official agreement from Bovis to purchase Galliford Try's Linden Homes and Partnerships & Regeneration business contains no changes to the acquisitions terms previously disclosed (a £1.075bn consideration). Completion date is expected to be 3 Jan 2020.
The placing of £157m of Bovis stock (9.99% of Bovis capital) will take place today with the funds going towards the purchase price. These shares will be eligible for the scrip dividend due in November (45p share) and the Bovis second interim dividend of 41p in May 2020.
The group indicates it has the capability to deliver 12,000 homes in the medium term, relative to JEFe of 10.2K in FY20.
For the first time Bovis has disclosed its planned targeted synergies: £35m by YE21. Of this £20m is targeted from operating costs and £15m from procurement (although we believe the latter number may have some upside potential).
Reflecting the higher balance sheet of Galliford at YE19 compared to when the acquisition was announced, Bovis now indicates a gearing including land creditors which is mid 30% when the deal is done, coming down to

A. M. @Nik: wait, are we talking about the shale producer of the same name?
11:58 am
BE11:58am

As we said at the time the deal was announced, the move to enlarge the housing business did not really add any value. The house builders still believe, despite years of evidence to the contrary, that becoming a bigger house builder makes you a better house builders but it doesn’t – it just makes you bigger. You suffer long periods or integration and elimination of overlap and, despite this being a key plank in the mind of the Bovis CEO, procurement savings are likely to be minimal. The materials suppliers and merchants are not gaining any more business and, we believe, are unlikely to offer larger discounts just because Bovis and Linden Homes have a single owner. On the labour side, provision of skilled worked is highly localised and house builders have little or no additional buying by being larger. Once you have already become a super-regional or national player, there is little labour cost saving to be secured.

The only real attraction for Bovis investors remains the partnership housing business which has the scope to raise the quality of earnings, align with a growth market and lower development/sales risk. Bovis was looking to move into this space on its own accounts but reaching scale and shaking off what is still a slightly tainted brand in a more sensitive end buyer market would have been tricky, we feel. Buying the Galliford brand and reputation gets the job done in one stroke. This division has the scope to raise the fair value of the group (clearly we do not think the enlargement of the core raises fair value) and we suggested when the deal was proposed that if the purchase proceeded (which was far from certain) we could see fair value edge up from 967p to nearer 1085p.
